The plane and boats had covered an extensive area of sea.Coastguards using mobile equipment searched along the shores of Arran and Kintyre.Nothing was seen.Police in Campbeltown began investigations into the matter shortly after the leboat put to sea their enquiries are continuing.ONE HUNDRED YEARS AGOAuchencorvie United, one of the teams that came into being in the rural area as a result of the formation of sports clubs among agricultural workers, made their first appearance in local competitive football last Saturday afternoon.Drumlemble supplied the opposition and had a comparatively easy victory by four goals to nil.Auchencorvie had several players of some promise but, as a whole, the team was sadly wanting in science and judgement and the lesson of their first experience should impress on them the fact that mere lusty vigour is not sufficient to win on the football field.In the first half, Drumlemble did not press their undoubted superiority unduly, being content with a one-goal lead at the interval. James Munro was the scorer.In the second half they added three more to the total, D Thomson having two and A Kerr one.At the opening concert of the winter session of the Scottish Clans# Association of London Mr Charles Kelly, a well-known Campbeltown vocalist, sang with much success.His pieces were The March of the Cameron Men, The Lea Rigg, I Passed By Your Window and Until.In all these numbers he had a fine reception, especially from Campbeltonians in the audience of whom there seemed to be a goodly number.A correspondent writing with regard to the work of the association says that there are probably a good many Kintyre folk in London who would find it a great pleasure to join the Scottish Clans and take part in society#s many s.The atmosphere is truly Scottish and the gatherings have a homeliness about them which appeals greatly to the newcomer.

title: late late show as pupils cruelly lose out
story: Campbeltown Pupils were left to rue the loss of another late goal last Saturday after an th-minute strike resigned the Kintyre Park side to a narrow defeat away to St Peter#s.Playing at Renfrew FC#s impressive New Western Park, the McFadyens-sponsored Pupils started the match brightly, despite another y injury list which saw several established first-team players ruled out and others unavailable due to work commitments.The Pupils took the lead before the -minute mark when John McCallum, playing at right wing in a --- formation, reacted quickest to Craig Lamont#s long throw-in, which bounced up on the dry synthetic surface, to guide a deft looping header beyond the reach of the St Peter#s keeper.The Kintyre side had efforts from left winger Scott Souden and lone striker Sean Grady go wide of the target – the latter#s promising effort deflected wide of goal – while McCallum was released by Grady and rounded the hosts# keeper only for his cutback to be cleared for a corner, away from the feet of the waiting Souden.At the other end, the Pupils had a new-look combination in defence, with full backs Craig Lamont and Michael McKinlay, and Ross Souden in central defence partnered by -year-old debutant Antonio Akoulli, studying in Scotland and hailing from Thessaloniki, Greece.The four had to be alert to the efforts of St Peter#s wingers Menzies and Lewis on either flank, and did so very well for the opening  minutes until a lapse in concentration saw Scott Lewis – signed from fellow WoSFL side Benburb FC for a transfer fee – ghost along the edge of the box and slot home a fine finish across keeper Alasdair Ferguson with his weaker left foot, into the young keeper’s bottom left-hand corner to make it -.Impressively, the Pupils rebounded from this setback and scored with  minutes played when Liam Renton, playing as an attacking midfielder, latched onto a ball from Scott Souden just inside the hosts# box, and turned his marker sharply before guiding a left-footed shot beyond the keeper#s grasp.All the while, the Pupils# deep-lying midfield pairing – a real contrast of experience levels between skipper Keith Mitchell, and Conner Brown beside him making his club debut – continued to break up play and keep the Feathers Inn-sponsored side moving forward.Despite this, there was a further scare in the visitors# penalty area when St Peter#s hit the bar from a powerful volleyed shot on the stroke of half time, but the Pupils# lead remained intact.Into the second half, though, the Pupils were pegged back in the opening few minutes of proceedings, a clever turn and precise shot beyond the grasp of Ferguson providing a fine equaliser.Admirably from a Pupils point of view, there was no onslaught from the ision#s third-placed team, also boasting a loan signing from Greenock FC, another semi-professional side, in their midfield ranks, and smatterings of semi-pro experience across their starting .However, what followed instead was a gradual build-up of pressure which the Pupils had to work increasingly hard to contain, the home side#s willing forwards continuing to probe for openings in the visitors# defence.The hard-working pair of Matthew Lang and Calum Houston were introduced in attack for the Pupils with  minutes remaining, with fresh legs required as the embattled visitors# energy levels began to wane.But even the dismissal of Lewis for the hosts, hitting out at Renton in reaction to a robust tackle from the latter, which earned the Pupils man a booking, couldn#t deny the Paisley side a late, late winner, a long ball going undefended in the Pupils ranks, and slotted home in the box by a St Peter#s midfielder to give them all three points, and in turn deny the Pupils a probably deserved draw.The Pupils# management team conveyed thanks to the travelling players for their efforts, even in defeat, and will surely take consolation from giving experience to young talent in the side, with four club debuts made in the space of week – after -year-old Andrew Renton#s appearance against Rossvale on cup duty – and within that clutch, a potentially very useful defensive addition.Tomorrow , the Pupils are at home to Glenvale FC, from Paisley, again on league duty, with kick off at pm.For more information, visit @PupilsAFC on Twitter or Campbeltown Football on Facebook.

title: leader october 29 2021
story: More must be done to prevent the continued spate of thefts which have  blighted Kintyre farms in recent years.To be targeted once must be incredibly frightening but some farmers have been targeted again and again, despite following advice to increase security and lock vehicles away.Maybe now that non-farming vehicles have also been stolen – a van in , a car in March  and another car last week – the wider community may realise the seriousness of the situation.The impact of rural crime takes a huge toll on the mental health of those who live in rural areas like Kintyre, many of whom choose to live here because of the low crime rates.It is therefore heartening that everyone the Courier spoke to in relation to the thefts seems genuinely keen to work collaboratively towards a solution.Parents must make sure their opinions are known about Argyll and Bute Council#s proposal to cluster some Argyll and Bute schools.No matter your opinion –you think an amalgamated Kintyre super-school would create a united front oryou think a dedicated headteacher for each school is better – you must make your voice heard.

title: letters october 29 2021
story: We know this winter is likely to be a dficult one for parents due to the risks caused by Respiratory Syncytial Virusinfections.RSV is a common virus that causes cold-like symptoms but can cause critical illnesses such as bronchiolitis in babies born premature or sick.RSV is usually most prevalent in Scotland between October and March each year.Throughout the Covid- pandemic, restrictions in social contact meant that cases of RSV were reduced. Since people began mixing again, there has steadily been an increase in cases ahead of the usual winter seasonal trend, mainly in children aged under five.Bliss will be working to provide information and support about RSV and respiratory infections directly to families of premature and sick babies at neonatal units across Scotland.We are urging all parents to know the warning signs of respiratory conditions and to contact their health care professional when they need to.In the early stages, RSV symptoms are similar to a common cold .Symptoms usually last between one and three weeks. If the lungs are affected, one or more of the following symptoms will develop or get worse:To find out more, please visit bliss.org.uk RSVA new campaign has been launched urging defibrillator owners to register their devices on a national database to help save more lives from cardiac arrests.Leading charities and health organisations are calling for defibrillators to be registered on The Circuit – the national defibrillator network, which connects defibrillators to NHS ambulance services across the UK.When someone calls  to report a cardiac arrest, call handlers are trained to provide the location of the nearest registered defibrillator within m of the call. Studies show that using a defibrillator within three minutes of collapse, along with starting CPR, can greatly increase chances of survival.This swt action can make a real dference, and The Circuit is a vital tool in helping increase bystander action to help someone in cardiac arrest.We would urge everyone to register the defibrillators that they are responsible for, so that they can be easily located and accessed when needed.It#s free to register your defibrillator onto The Circuit, and you only have to do it once. You can also register multiple defibrillatorsyou areto more than one.Visit www.thecircuit.uk for more information.

title: team nets new bags
story: The purchase of the holdalls was possible thanks to a donation to the under s team from Wylie Hume.#Everyone involved at the s would like to say a massive thanks to Wylie for his kind donation,# said David Paterson, team manager.#As many will know, Wylie himself was heavily involved in the local children#s football association in the s and s and wished to show support to our efforts.#Along with a small payment from parents, rucksacks were also purchased with Campbeltown and District Juvenile Football Association#s help – as is the case for all age groups in the association.#Thanks from all involved at the s.#

title: thought for the week october 29 2021
story: Although the autumn marks the end of summer, for many looking ahead, it#s filled with excitement and anticipation as Christmas approaches. The countdown begins!There are many good things in le we look forward to: a sunny day, a bike ride, the weekend, holidays, retirement or a new job.At dferent times we look forward to dferent things, but behind them all is a common search.The French scientist and mathematician Blaise Pascal said: #All people seek happiness. This is without exception##He said that whatever our idea of how to reach it, our desire never takes the smallest step except towards the goal of happiness it is the desire behind every ambition.But from time to time we recognise our search is misleading, happiness doesn#t last, the clouds come, the ride ends, Monday morning always follows#Three time Wimbledon champion Boris Becker said: #I had won Wimbledon twice before, once as the youngest player. I was rich I had all the material possessions I needed.#It#s the old song of movie stars# they have everything, and yet they are so unhappy. I had no inner peace, I was a puppet on a string.#Where, then, is lasting happiness to be found The bible teaches us that every wonderful thing we enjoy is both a gt and sign pointing us to the giver, our creator God who loves us.If we hope to find ultimate happiness in His gts, we expect too much#We were designed through those gts to enjoy the God who gave them and to find true joy in Him.#I have come [said Jesus] that you may have le and have it to the full.#

title: west coast motors 100 years of bringing people together part iii
story: A century after Campbeltown-based coach operator West Coast Motors was founded, bus enthusiast Lawrence Macduff, who splits his time between Kilmarnock and Dunoon, has penned a commemorate article delving into the company#s history from  to the present day.The piece, and several photographs also supplied by Lawrence, is being published in the Courier. Photographs from the early days up to  are from the collections of the late Robert Grieves and from John Sinclair, two indefatigable photographers whose material is of national Scottish importance. This week#s article is the conclusion.West Coast#s business portfolio now extends well beyond Kintyre.In , it bought the Glasgow Citybus concern which operates on the north side of the Clyde.Two years on, it also picked up a city tour business which is now operated under the City Sightseeing franchise in Glasgow.It also operates the inter-rail station shuttle in the city.An interesting ersication in  was what became a fast passenger ferry link from Campbeltown to Ballycastle while a few years further on, Fairline Coaches, based near the company#s Glasgow Citybus depot in Whiteinch, Glasgow, was absorbed into West Coast.The company also won the contract to operate Citylink#s new Glasgow-Edinburgh Airport service and additionally, partnered Fort William-based Shiel Buses on Citylink#s Glasgow-Fort William and Skye services.Perhaps the biggest and most signicant recent extension of West Coast#s business came with the creation of Borders Buses. The company acquired services radiating into the region from Edinburgh as well local route networks taking it as far south as Berwick on Tweed.As a result, the West Coast identity is to be found all over the Borders.Combined vehicle strength is now around , a far cry from fewer than  in the s.I#d like to conclude this abbreviated survey with two final observations. Firstly, I wish to acknowledge and applaud the drive and foresight of the Craig family in building the business from its original heartland in the southernmost area of Argyll.Public transport is full of challenges whether air, sea, rail or road and, as in every field of business le, there are never any guarantees of success.Once any business reaches a successful position, it often requires even more effort to maintain it there, let alone continue to grow it in size and influence.The presence of Covid since  has, of course, created major dficulties for every business virtually across the board.Finally, a word of praise for the staff and especially for those who are engaged on the vital long-distance links, particularly the Campbeltown, Oban and Skye services.These routes are not only amongst the most weather prone in Scotland, they operate almost exclusively over ordinary trunk roads, iniably convoluted in nature and of borderline width for the safe transit of long vehicles.A driver myself, though never on any of these routes, I#m familiar with all these roads and have some perception of the extreme challenges drivers frequently face.To them, and to all the company#s staff and management, I, and I#m sure many readers who are users of the services West Coast Motors provide across Argyll and in other parts of Scotland, offer grateful thanks.

title: muddy good rugby festival at taynuilt
story: More than  players from Campbeltown, Lochgilphead, Oban, Fort William, Mull and Taynuilt took part with some fantastic rugby on display across all the age groups from the Micro P-Ps to the P s.Conditions were damp under foot given the amount of rain that has been falling lately. The rain on the day did not dampen the enthusiasm of everyone taking revelling in rolling about in the mud.Congratulations to Kintyre who won both the P  and the P  competitions. They had a real desire to compete and were deserved winners.It was also great to see Mull being represented again after missing the last few festivals and they acquitted themselves well in their first games under their new coaches.A big game of girls touch rugby topped off a great day with all the girls taking part to celebrate Women and Girls in Sport week. This was one of the highlights of the day with the youngest player in P all the way through to the P’sA big thank you to everyone at Etive Vikings for their hospitality. The last festival of the season will take place at Lochaber Rugby Club, Fort William on Sunday November .All pics in D photosMain photograph : Isle of Mull players take a well earned rest.

title: muddy good rugby festival at taynuilt 2
story: Youngsters from the Kintyre-Campbeltown team joined players from Lochgilphead, Oban, Fort William, Mull and Taynuilt, with some fantastic rugby on display across all the age groups from the micro P-Ps to the P-s.Conditions were damp underfoot, given the amount of rain that has been falling lately.But the rain on the day did not dampen the enthusiasm of everyone revelling in rolling about in the mud.#Congratulations to Kintyre who won both the P  and the P  competitions,# said a spokesperson. #They had a real desire to compete and were deserved winners.#It was also great to see Mull being represented again after missing the last few festivals and they acquitted themselves well in their first games under their new coaches.#A big game of girls# touch rugby topped off a great day with all the girls taking part to celebrate Women and Girls in Sport week.This was one of the highlights of the day with the youngest player in P, all the way through to the Ps.The last festival of the season will take place at Lochaber Rugby Club, Fort William on Sunday November .

title: pupils u15s defeated by top of the league team
story: Campbeltown Pupils shosted top-of-the-league Clyde Community s last Sunday, in their first home game in ision one.The Kintyre side has been working hard on the fundamentals of football and managing to hit the mark.Both teams started the game very strong and it was a great first-half from the local side, with the scoreline level at - when the half-time whistle blew.The travelling Clyde side found their feet very quickly in the second half and held a strong back four which the Campbeltown side could not penetrate.With the visitors# scoring three further goals, the final score was Campbeltown Pupils , Clyde Community .

title: spooky sporting activities
story: Participants of both sports dressed up as they took part in activities last Sunday, on October , All Hallows# Eve itself.Paddleboarders dressed up as witches, a cowgirl, Ghostface and sported spooky head boppers as they enjoyed a ride on Campbeltown Loch.And young golfers donned their glow-in-the-dark gear as they took part in an evening competition at Machrihanish Golf Club before changing into their own frightening costumes for a party in the clubhouse afterwards.

title: amazons first uk windfarm comes online in kintyre
story: The company has announced it will purchase  per cent of the power output from ScottishPower Renewables# Beinn an Tuirc  windfarm.The largest ScottishPower windfarm to be built without a government support scheme, its construction was enabled by Amazon#s Power Purchase Agreement The MW, -turbine windfarm is now generating enough electricity to power the equivalent of almost , homes, bringing more green energy on to the UK grid.The energy generated will power Amazon and Amazon Web Servicesdata centres, corporate offices and fulfilment centres across the UK.PPAs allow developers to invest in and build new green infrastructure projects with a clear route to market and without relying on public funding for renewable energy while corporate customers benefit from a trusted source of clean energy, certainty, and a reduction in their own carbon footprint.Speaking last week, Lindsay McQuade, chief executive officer of ScottishPower Renewables, said: #It#s really exciting to mark the completion of Beinn an Tuirc  and the start of our PPA with Amazon during UK Wind Week and with just a few days to go until the COP UN Climate Change Conference gets underway.#If we#re going to reach net zero over the next  years, we need to quadruple the amount of renewable energy produced in the UK so we can move away from petrol and diesel cars electry public transport get rid of gas boilers and move to electric heating for our homes and lower emissions from heavy industry and the goods and services we rely on every day.#We#re proud to have delivered Amazon#s first renewable project in the UK, supporting The Climate Pledge and the company#s commitment to be net-zero carbon across its business by .#This will support a greener and more sustainable economy and help us all enjoy a cleaner and better future, quicker.#John Boumphrey, Amazon#s UK country manager, added: #Amazon is on a path to powering our operations with  per cent renewable energy by , five years ahead of schedule.#We are excited that our first Scottish windfarm is now contributing to that goal, and we have three more large-scale renewable projects in development across the UK.#Investing in clean energy and working across all of our operations to become more efficient is just one of the many actions we are taking to reach our commitment as part of The Climate Pledge to be net-zero carbon by .#South Kintyre#s three councillors welcomed the news and the potential benefits it could bring to Kintyre.Councillor John Armour said: #I am delighted that Kintyre has been chosen and recognised in taking this forward.#It highlights the fact that with the right will from all concerned Kintyre can be a hub for future wind turbine production and for work connected with the ongoing maintenance of windfarms.#We have a purpose-built factory and top-class workforce so we need to see all parties working together to bring this all together.#Argyll First Councillor Donald Kelly added: #It is encouraging that Amazon is trying to reduce its carbon footprint through investing in Beinn an Tuirc .#This certainly raises the profile of Kintyre#s capability to be part of the ongoing drive to deliver onshore renewable energy projects.#Councillor Rory Colville said: #Whilst this partnership approach has undoubtedly put Kintyre on the map, what could be truly transformational isAmazon, using energy direct from Beinn an Tuirc , based its AWS data centre here in Kintyre.#Recently, MACC Business Park was promoted in the national press as a site for a new green datacentre all it needs is for some or all of the new proposed transatlantic cable to be channelled in to the base. It could be the start of a whole new industry.#In other green energy news, Chancellor Rishi Sunak has awarded a funding package to a Kintyre-based hydrogen production and distribution project under the UK Government#s Community Renewal Fund.As outlined in the Chancellor#s Budget, £, has been awarded to the MACC Hydrogen Futures viability study, through which Machrihanish Airbase Community Company plans to complete a detailed feasibility and design project with a view to establishing a green hydrogen production and distribution facility.£, was also awarded to help fund feasibility studies, business plans, investment cases and planning applications as a prelude to a £ million transformation project to regenerate Tarbert.Highlands and Islands MSP Donald Cameron said: #These investment packages from Rishi Sunak are welcome news for Argyll and Bute, and in particular Kintyre.#The chancellor#s financial support from the Community Renewal Fund means that people living in Kintyre will see the benefits of these extremely worthwhile projects that look to regenerate or innovate within their area.#

title: council pledges to keep working with community projects post pandemic
story: An update by the Accounts Commission and Audit Scotland highlighted the authority#s work in the community since the Covid- outbreak and has now called for the momentum to be maintained by councils across Scotland, alongside a determination not toto pre-pandemic ways of working.In response to the call, Argyll and Bute Council highlighted many examples of its work with communities since March .A spokesperson for the council said: #We worked with our partners throughout the pandemic to deliver our communities with a range of support services.#There was huge pressure placed on local businesses and restrictions on how to trade during lockdown and one of the many things we did to help was establish a town centre recovery group during the first weeks of the pandemic.#This included representatives across council services, the police and the private sector, and allowed quick actions to be taken to enable businesses to ersy and adapt to meet customer needs.#For example, easing the need for planning consents and enabling more use of outdoor space including on council land.#These meetings led to further initiatives including a shop local campaign, shopfront grants, permanent improvements to outdoor spaces and digital apps s to help local business prosper and provide information to their customers.#The spokesperson added: #Our joint approach to protecting the most vulnerable people in our society also led to our Community Food Project beating off industry giants to win a national award.#We have continued to work at pace on the development and delivery of the Covid- Micro Grant Fund for village halls and community organisations.#This fund was set up to help communities to recover from the impacts of Covid- and find safe ways to bring people together.#Covid- has had a huge impact on our society and we continue to meet with community response groups on a monthly basis to identy their needs and escalate concerns to partners and other services as required.#Geraldine Wooley from the Accounts Commission said: #Covid- made some public bodies quickly deliver services dferently. In many places, voluntary sector organisations were able to work at pace and with a greater freedom to support their communities.#Community organisations across Scotland have a depth of understanding about local needs, that we should continue to tap into.#They were able to identy those who were most vulnerable, bringing insight into very local issues. Their ability to quickly maximise local knowledge and connections was crucial in the local response.#We urge councils to build on this and notto business as usual. Truly empowered communities are vital in helping reduce the disadvantage and inequalities that have become more severe because of Covid-.#

title: district news november 5 2021
story: In the future, a trip to the city for Kintyre residents could mean taking the long and winding road to Oban instead of Glasgow.Argyll and Bute residents are being urged to get behind the town#s bid to be one of the UK#s newest cities.Cities come in all shapes and sizes and Oban could become one of them in , fighting off stf competition from other towns in the national competition marking the Queen#s platinum jubilee.As part of a campaign headed #Oban – Scotland in one place#, our sister newspaper The Oban Times has joined forces with Argyll and Bute Council to champion the town as a worthy contender for city status.Now council leader Robin Currie is inviting people to get involved and share what they like best about Oban.People#s comments and photographs about what makes Oban a special place to live, work and visit could make all the dference to the town#s bid.Backing the bid is one step of making sure that the town and Argyll has as much chance of a successful future as other parts of Scotland, says Councillor Currie.Council officers are hard at work getting the big bid ready to meet the deadline on December , but need people#s help.Visit www.argyll-bute.gov.uk obancity to share your support and to find out more about the bid and what it could mean for the town. You can send your photographs to workingtogether@argyll-bute.gov.ukCouncillor Currie said: #City status is about creating opportunities for investment to progress things that matter to local people, for example infrastructure or housing, that are beyond the resources of the council.#Being a rural Scottish city would mean, for example, that Oban could be included in government city initiatives as well as rural growth initiatives.#New leisure or community facilities as well as green spaces could be created as a result of a successful bid.Public support so far has been great says Argyll and Bute Council#s head of development and economic growth Fergus Murray.#We understand, too, of course, that there could be questions about what city status might mean for the area and have provided information in response on our website,# he said.#There#s stf competition out there for the skills, jobs and investment Argyll and Bute needs.#Bidding for city status will help with this by raising the profile of the area as a great place to invest, visit and live.#Oban was picked as Argyll and Bute#s city contender because it was deemed to have the highest chance of winning.Being a top tourist destination with good travel links, as well as having one of the UK#s busiest ferry ports and being a gateway to a number of island communities are all plus points.Already having University Town status with in excess of , students, including the world renowned SAMSinstitute, also goes in Oban#s favour, as well as it being such a popular place to live and visit.

title: helping to preserve kintyres coach heritage
story: As well as penning a commemorative piece to mark the th anniversary of the founding of West Coast Motors, bus enthusiast Lawrence Macduff is keeping Kintyre#s coach history alive by preserving one of the company#s vintage vehicles.Lawrence, who splits his time between Kilmarnock and Dunoon, was the author of a three-part commemorate article which featured in the Courier over the last three weeks.It formed the basis for several displays that Lawrence took, along with a newly retired West Coast Motors service coach that he and a friend purchased for preservation just before lockdown, to the Glasgow Vintage Vehicle Trust#s annual open weekend on Saturday October  and Sunday October .Despite Covid restrictions, the newly preserved DAF coach made its maiden show appearance in Dunfermline in August.The information on Campbeltown-based West Coast Motors# history was mounted on to four boards, one featuring an introduction, one covering from the s to , another from  to , and the final board bringing the story to around .They were joined by several other boards concentrated on West Coast Motors# Argyll operations, covering Cowal, Bute, Oban and Mull, what could be called the company#s homeland.

title: leader november 5 2021
story: It can be a bit overwhelming when we are told climate change is #the greatest threat to our existence in our short history on this planet# and that humanity is facing #code red#.As the world#s biggest powers debate the best ways to combat the climate challenges we all face, it would be easy to give up in the belief our inidual actions will have little or no impact on the bigger picture.But the cumulative impact of everyone making a few small changes could have a huge  dference.We don#t all have to rush to buy an electric car – how about buying a reusable cup for your coffee instead of using a disposable plastic cup every day, or turning off lights when leaving a room to help save energy Every little helps.Well done to Beinn an Tuirc Distillers for winning two awards at the Scottish Gin Awards.It is worth noting the distillery#s prizewinning spirits are sustainably produced using the company#s own renewable energy from its small hydro-electric scheme.That means those of us in Kintyre can enjoy a guilt-free tipple as we ponder the challenges of climate change, knowing the gin is produced in an environmentally sustainable way, with low delivery mileage!

title: letters november 5 2021
story: The SNP government#s refusal to heed recommendations from CalMac on how many new ferries the operator required to service its routes has led directly to the crisis that has overtaken Scotland#s ferry service.No fewer than  of CalMac#s  active vessels are now more than  years old, which is the recommended operational lespan of a ferry.A debate on the on-going ferry crisis took place this week at the Scottish Parliament.It was very telling that those SNP members who took part in the debate were quite unable, or unwilling, to launch a defence of their own government#s record when it comes to the crisis affecting our ferry service.They know, as we all do, that SNP ministers have failed in their duty of care to our island communities and that excuses will no longer cut it.Nicola Sturgeon now needs to admit her government#s -year failure to protect our leline ferry service, and then actually do something about it, and quickly.I am appealing for used postage stamps which help me raise funds which I then donate to the Guide Dogs for the Blind.Recycling used postage stamps is such an easy way to raise money for the charity and I am always in need of all types of postage stamps, including British, foreign and Christmas stamps.If you are able to help I would be gratefulyou could cut the stamps from their envelopes, leaving approximately cm margin around the stamp, and send them to: Myrna Chave, PO Box , Virginia Water, Surrey, GU ARThank you to everyone who has donated in the past, your assistance in helping me to support this very worthy cause is greatly appreciated.My email address is stampsgdftb@live for more information.

title: photograph of the week november 5 2021
story: #We were looking at the standing stones when a wee treecreeper flew in under the roof, saw us, panicked and turned left straight into a wall and knocked himself out for a wee minute,# Kevin said.#We picked him up and checked him over and kept him safe until he was right as rain again.#We managed to get some beautul pictures of the little fellow. The birds are very well camouflaged in the trees so can be a rare find to see close up.#If you have a photograph you would like to share, please email it to editor@campbeltowncourier or send it via the Courier#s Facebook page.

title: thought for the week november 5 2021
story: There are two kinds of silence.There is the kind that numbs and kills, the kind Simon and Garfunkel sang about.It is the silence imposed upon people – that refuses to hear the cry of the hurt, the wounded, the lonely, the unemployed, the hungry, the vulnerable.Veteransfrom wars, and the daily papers strike glorious attitudes. Suffering from unspeakable trauma, they retreat into silence.Breadwinners lose their jobs, and are condemned to poverty, loss of home, reliance on food banks, endless indignity.Young people struggle with mental illness earth and sea, animal and insect le, struggle beneath the load of pollution – and are met with silence.That silence, the silence of the neon god, breeds lies – lies that threaten our planet, our lives and our souls.But there is a dferent kind of silence: a kindly, warm, nurturing silence.It is the silence of the rich humus of mother earth. It is the amniotic fluid bathing our souls for healing. It is out of that silence alone # the Spirit#s silence # that truth springs, and with truth, justice. And with justice, peace, and the healing touch of love.COP is upon us. Amid all the noisy voices, which kind of silence will we choose  Which kind of silence will we permit  Complicity, or graciousness Mercy and peace have met together,

title: kintyre holiday park expansion is creating new jobs
story: The £, project by Machrihanish Holiday Park will improve the site#s accommodation and facilities, increasing the number of holiday homes available to rent and buy.A sports court will be created, along with a new reception building.Accessibility improvements are being made, and ramps installed for toilet and shower facilities.The project will enable the company to grow by increasing the number of the park#s holiday home pitches from  to  over the next three years, complementing its existing  touring pitches.The improvements have helped to safeguard the existing . full time equivalentjobs at the park and have created a further four FTE posts.Recruitment for another three FTE roles is also planned for .Machrihanish Holiday Park forms part of the re-emerging holiday resort village of Machrihanish.The current owners have been investing in the park continuously since , transforming it from a two-star to a four-star park.The business has benefited from growth in demand for self-catering staycations.With this growth set to continue, the park is expected to benefit further from the staycation market.#There has been strong demand for self-catering, touring and camping holidays in Scotland since lockdown has ended and Kintyre has a lot to offer tourists looking for wide open spaces, miles of beaches, world-class golf and famous distilleries,# said Ian Aitkin of Machrihanish Holiday Park.#Our improvement project, with help from HIE, will enable us to expand and improve the park, providing visitors with five-star facilities.#Morag Goodfellow, HIE#s area manager for Argyll and the Islands, said: #Tourism has had a very dficult time but is also key to our region#s recovery.#The resilience and commitment shown by businesses in the sector has been amazing. Many continue to adapt, innovate and provide memorable and enjoyable experiences for visitors.#Machrihanish Holiday Park is a great example. With Argyll in an ideal position to benefit from the rise in staycations, from people across Scotland and the UK, it has taken the initiative to capitalise on this market growth.#This very welcome project will enhance the wider visitor offering, help attract more visitors and encourage longer stays in the area.#As well as supporting valuable jobs in a rural area, the expected increase in visitors is also likely to benefit other local businesses.#We are very pleased to be able to provide support and look forward to continuing to work with the business as they implement the plans.#Machrihanish Holiday Park is open for holiday home and hot-tub lodge rentals throughout the winter.Visit campkintyre or call    for more information or to book a break.

title: minato-sushi-cheese-lady-boost-haddington-town-centre
story: The Cheese Lady on Haddington High Street is moving into the former butcher premises of Colin D Peat on neighbouring Court Street.The move from High Street has opened the door for Minato Sushi to bring the Japanese delicacy to the town centre.The changing face of the town centre was welcomed by councillors Tom Trotter and John McMillan, with the new businesses set to open this summer.Jen Kerr, of Minato Sushi, stressed there was still plenty of work ahead at the business before the doors opened.The -year-old, of Port Seton, who will run the business with her boyfriend Tom Cuddy, described it as ldquoa real dream come true.She said: ldquoWe are really excited. It is quite a big town centre in East Lothian and has quite a erse mix of businesses there already. It seems nice and some people have been coming up and chatting to me and other shop owners have been quite friendly.Meanwhile, Svetlana Kukharchuk ndash The Cheese Lady ndash has ambitious plans for the former butchers having found a home for her business in the town nearly four years ago.She said: ldquoWe needed more space and wanted to expand so we can offer more space to our customers to shop more conveniently.ldquoWe want to mature our own cheeses and we are going to have a maturation room.ldquoAlso, Irsquom hoping to offer a few tables, which still needs to be confirmed with the council, where people can sit down and order a flight of cheese and a glass of wine.Svetlana, who previously had a business in St Andrews, moved to East Lothian in November  and opened her High Street shop.The business has proven a popular addition to the town centre, offering cheeses from throughout Europe, including Italy, France, Spain, Switzerland and Norway.Mr Trotter was pleased with the announcement regarding the two businesses.He said: ldquoWhoever thought a cheese shop in Haddington that, after this time, needed bigger premises  Thatrsquos fantastic.ldquoAnd it is incredible we are getting a sushi shop.Fellow ward member Mr McMillan was pleased with the level of interest from people looking to open up businesses in the town.He said: ldquoI think we are in a good place.ldquoWhen we were growing up, we did not know what sushi was!

title: youngsters-12-hour-non-stop-relay-boosts-walk-scott-foundation
story: Mary Kidd spent a day running, cycling, skipping and more in aid of the Walk With Scott Foundation.The -hour non-stop relay on May  has collected more than pound,, which will go to the Tranent-based charity.Proud mum Karen is secretary of the Walk With Scott Foundation, which was set up by after-dinner speaker Scott Glynn to mark his th birthday.Karen thanked everyone who sponsored her -year-old daughter, who also undertook a fundraiser for the charity last year during lockdown.Karen said: ldquoWe are all so very proud of Mary once again, with her amazingly crazy two fundraising events.ldquoMary has raised a fantastic pound, for the Walk with Scott Foundation and I know first-hand how much these funds are going to help others across our communities.Last year, the primary six pupil at Cockenzie Primary School completed a six-hour TikTok marathon, which raised pound, for the Walk With Scott Foundation.: Familys television appearanceThe success of the fundraiser even caught the attention of former Spandau Ballet and EastEnders star Martin Kemp and his son Roman. Mary and Karen were joined by dad Gordon and older sister Abbie on Martin and Romanrsquos Sunday Best TV show to discuss the success of the event.However, Mary was not content to put her feet up and was once again doing her bit for the good cause.Speaking ahead of the latest fundraiser, Mary said: ldquoThis year I want to double the time, and plan to do a -hour non-stop fun relay up and down our Lorimer Lane at the back of my house.ldquoIrsquom walking, running, skipping, hopping, jumping, scootering, cycling, skating, football dribbling, swing ball, space hopping and, of course, TikTok-ing!People can still sponsor Mary by going to uk.virginmoneygiving marysfunrelay

title: towns-corn-exchange-opened-one-off-test-run
story: Haddingtonrsquos Corn Exchange has been closed to the public since February  while it has undergone refurbishment works.The building was due to reopen in November of that year but the date has been pushed back, firstly by a need for ldquofurther intrusive survey work and then the coronavirus pandemic.It is unlikely that groups will be back in the building, which is used by the townrsquos community council and ious other clubs and organisations, until next year.However, it was opened for the Most Venerable Order of St John of Jerusalem at the beginning of the month, with the Priory of Scotland of the Order of St John holding the annual Service and Investiture of Postulants and promotions of members at St Maryrsquos Parish Church.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council confirmed that the venue had been used by a group on October .She said: ldquoAccess to Haddington Corn Exchange for community groups and events is unlikely to be possible until .ldquoThis is due to a combination of continued dficulties experienced, with staff shortages around the pandemic and Brexit, and our need to prioritise enhanced school cleaning regimes, as well as in the shorter term a number of outstanding snagging issues requiring to be completed in the building.ldquoA long-standing booking was honoured earlier this month, with the event providing a one-off lsquotest runrsquo for the facility. However, it is clear that the staffing support required, combined with some outstanding works and safety measures, means that the Corn Exchange is not yet available for regular use.Provost John McMillan, who attended the two events, said that the booking had been made about  months ago on the assumption that the work within the Corn Exchange would be complete.However, the test run had highlighted issues which meant the venue was not yet ready for day-to-day use.The situation at the building was highlighted at the townrsquos community council earlier this month.Fiona McEwan, secretary of the group, had been in touch with East Lothian Council to askthe building could be used during the marking of Armistice Day but was told the venue would likely not be open until the new year.She added: ldquoI have heard through the grapevine of there being a few groups, one in the Corn Exchange last weekend and another scheduled for this weekend, that are getting to use it.Diann Govenlock, from the townrsquos area partnership, was also at the meeting.She confirmed there were still ldquosnagging issues being addressed, as well as problems with the gentsrsquo toilets and heating in the rear hall.The pound, refurbishment includes new roof lights in the main hall, as well as repairs to the roof and timber flooring. A new storage area, new kitchen and additional toilets were also included in the works.

title: new-home-derelict-site-gets-go-ahead
story: The arcade, on Dunbarrsquos Lamer Street, closed its doors about  years ago and was later demolished. Planning permission was given for a two-storey home on the site  months ago.Changes to the style meant a fresh application was needed, which has now been given the go-ahead by East Lothian Council.Dunbar Community Council was supportive of the plans, which, according to the planning officerrsquos report, saw ldquoan opportunity to regenerate the area and bring it back into use in the form of a habitable home.Pippa Swan, community council chairwoman, hoped progress could now be made on the site, which has been used as an unofficial car park in recent years.When the proposals were revealed earlier this summer, she said: ldquoThe site has been derelict for so long. It was a blight on the shorefront.ldquoIt would have been really nice to find a way to bring it into public use but that did not happen.ldquoFrom my point of view, it is far better it is put to good use to make a nice house than left.Plans for the site show two studios alongside two lounges, a kitchen dining area and a third bedroom on the ground floor.Upstairs would feature a master bedroom and terrace, along with a bathroom and dressing room.Documents included with the application note: ldquoThe contemporary design approach to the dwelling house has been retained and developed with little perceptible change and shall provide an outstanding architectural statement to support the historic evolution of Dunbar waterfront.

title: south-african-barbecue-street-food-van-longniddry-bents-gets-go-ahead
story: Edinburgh-based BBQ StreetFood applied for planning permission to bring its mobile rotisserie to Longniddry Bents No  car park after East Lothian Council advertised a potential snack van site there.However, concerns over road safety saw conditions attached to the permission ruling that the snack van, which is described as a .-metre-long trailer, cannot turn right into the car park on arrival each day or when leaving it.Councillors imposed the condition after visiting the car park, which lies on a bendy stretch of the East Lothian coast road, and raising concerns about fast-moving traffic.The move means that when arriving from its current storage site in Portobello, it will automatically turn left however, when leaving, the mobile trailer will have to head half a mile east before being able to turn right up towards Longniddry Railway Station to double back.And the owner of the snack van was also ordered to bring his own bins to the site, which has not had a bin for  years.Concerns about litter at the beach were raised by councillors and Longniddry Community Council chairwoman Helen York during a virtual planning meeting on Tuesday.The meeting was told that bins were not provided at Longniddry Bents because they encouraged littering.Neil Clark,from the councilrsquos countryside rangers service, said the no litter bins strategy had been a ldquohuge success.He said: ldquoLongniddry Bents was a dficult site to manage. At its very worst, we had litter and rats to deal with.ldquoWe have no litter bins and have had none for  years. Not having litter bins has been a huge success story.The new snack van was described by applicant Andre De Villiers as an upmarket rotisserie which would be serving chicken and ribs.He told the committee: ldquoAll our packaging is biodegradable, from knives and forks to packing itself, there is no plastic involved.ldquoThis is not a takeaway van, it is a fully bespoke rotisserie.Applying for planning permission, the company said it planned to operate at the car park from .am to .pm from November to February and then .am to .pm from March to October.Ms York told the committee that there were concerns about litter caused by customers taking food onto the beach from the car park.And she hit out at the council for advertising sites at its coastal car parks without ldquopublic consultation.She said: ldquoAs a community council, we would have liked to have seen a sustainable tourism policy before East Lothian Council started advertising trade stands.ldquoThere is a lot of anger from other community councils about this being slipped in with no discussion.And she warned that advertising boards for snack vans would ldquoclutter the coast road.She said: ldquoWhat about the people who just want to visit beaches and countryside  They do not want the smell of fried food or having discussion with children about buying food when they arrive at the beach. They want a cheap day out.However, ward councillor Lachlan Bruce said that people wanted more to be available when they came to the county.He said: ldquoI have heard from people using the beaches who live locally and further away. They want more to do while there.The committee granted temporary planning permission for the the new street food vendor for one year only to allow its impact to be reviewed in the future.

title: not-happy-all-loss-recycling-wheelie-bins-rural-residents
story: Simon Booth, , of Cairndinnis Cottages, east of Haddington, is upset with the switch away from recycling wheelie bins in rural parts of East Lothian.All of East Lothian will move to weekly recycling collections from next Monday , with recycling to be separated into four streams: paper and card in a blue box cardboard in a separate blue box or a larger cardboard box glass bottles and jars in a green or black box and plastic, cans and cartons in a new weighted bag.The system will retain the blue and green black boxes already used for recycling in most parts of the county ndash however, some rural areas have until now had wheelie bins for recycling.There are approximately , rural households in East Lothian and they make up about . per cent of the total number of households in the county .Security officer Mr Booth said: ldquoWhen the recycling was set up years ago it was deemed that boxes were unsuitable for rural areas due to weather conditions and distance that collection points could be from the address but now theyrsquove changed their minds, so wersquove now got boxes.ldquoIrsquom not at all happy, it is totally unsuitable for what we need. In adverse weather it is more likely a collection could be missed.ldquoIt is very windy where we are so they will get blown all over the place.Wersquove also got quite a distance between the collection point, so instead of wheeling two bins out, we will now have to carry two boxes, loose cardboard, a food carrier and a sack.ldquoThe council has pushed through these changes without public consultation.He feared the changes would ldquoreduce the number of people recycling and would disadvantage older and disabled residents, who would have to carry the boxes to the kerbside.Mr Booth added: ldquoThis in itself is a health and safety issue. The council may offer an assisted collection but many people are too proud to use that.He also said there were increasing hygiene issues in rural areas, adding: ldquoI live on a working farm and often the lane is covered in cow dung. We are going to end up with manure in the boxes or on ourselves when the boxes are moved.ldquoWill the council collect boxes contaminated with cow dung And he claimed: ldquoldquoMany East Lothian residents have for many years complained about these recycling boxes as being totally unsuitable for their needs and, instead of listening to the taxpayers of East Lothian, the council has forced through the changes and made the system more complex. For people to engage, the collection system must be simple to understand.Another rural resident, Helen Robertson, of Quarryford, near Gford, wrote to the Courier to express her dismay at the loss of the recycling wheelie bins .An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoThe new recycling collections will be a weekly service rather than fortnightly, which potentially means each household, whilst being able to recycle more, will present less than they currently do on a fortnightly collection.ldquoThis system is a county-wide system and an assisted service is available for householders who, through disability, age or ill health, are not able to present their containers for collection and have no one living at the household who can assist.The new recycling service in East Lothian had been due to launch in September but was pushed back to November due to problems with the delivery of the new weighted bags.The local authority says that the ldquorefreshed recycling service is designed to help residents recycle more than ever before with all materials collected by a single vehicle into separated compartments.

title: halloween-gallery-musselburgh-burgh-primary-school-celebrates-style
story: Children across the school took part in ious in class activities including potion making, pumpkin carving, Halloween science and crafts, alongside lots of singing and dancing.A Musselburgh Burgh Primary Schoolspokesperson said: "Each class took part in a costume parade where our dinner-lady Linda and our janitor Roddie had the very tricky task of picking their favourite costumes from every class."Everyone had a great day and there was lots of smiles to be seen across the whole school."

title: youths-allegedly-vandalise-house-port-seton-halloween
story: The home, on Castle Terrace, was damaged by a group of youths ndash mostly young boys ndash on Sunday evening.The homeowner said that five of them approached and knocked on the front door but, as no one was home, there was no answer.Upon leaving the property, two of the five boys allegedly picked up stones from the driveway and threw them at a bedroom window at the front of the property, causing two holes in the double-glazed unit.The estimated damage to the windows is pound.The incident, which was caught on CCTV, has been reported to police.

title: former-guides-celebrated-90-years-combined-service
story: Margaret Craigie and Frances Monaghan, from Musselburgh, have both been members of the guild ndash which offers social opportunities and supports Girlguiding ndash for  years, having joined in .They received their badges from Lorraine Dickson, East Lothian County Commissioner, at a presentation at the Fisherrow Centre on South Street where the guild meets. Afterwards, a lsquosilhouettersquo quiz was enjoyed, followed by cake and tea.The Trefoil Guild, which is open to women and men over the age of , also supports Scouting.Members meet with friends, develop interests, tackle new challenges, enjoy outings and holidays together. They help Girlguiding at district, ision, county, region, UK and international level.Margaret Craigie joined the Brownies in Musselburgh in  and went on to become a Guide. She became a Brownie Guider in the rd Musselburgh Brownies in the s.Frances was a Brownie and Guide in Campbeltown. In Musselburgh, she was an adult helper with the th Musselburgh Brownie pack.Frances said that when she moved to Musselburgh after she married, and as a new mum, she found friendship with the guild, which had a membership of nearly  in the s. She also enjoyed helping to arrange outings and Christmas meals over the years.

title: knox-academy-pupils-selling-poppies-tesco-part-annual-fundraising-efforts
story: Pupils at Knox Academy have fundraised for Poppyscotland for more than five years but were unable to put collection tins in the townrsquos stores last year due to the pandemic.Sue Cook, headteacher at the Haddington secondary school, was pleased to say fundraising efforts were up and running once again.She said: ldquoAll poppies and tins have now been distributed in the town and pupils will be in Tesco this weekend, November  and .A bake sale with poppy cupcakes and biscuits will also take place in the school.All money raised will be used to provide support for current and former members of the armed forces and their families.

title: pictures-communities-unite-climate-change-vigils-north-berwick-east-linton
story: The North Berwick West Beach event, organised by Sustaining North Berwick, gathered members of the public to share their fears on the climate crisis and their opinions on what governments should do to halt the global rise in temperature.And Paul McLennan MSP said he was delighted by the childrenrsquos knowledge of the subject.He said: ldquoItrsquos great to see so many kids, because it is about their future.ldquoWe need to keep the pressure up on world leaders, on leaders in Scotland and the UK.ldquoThe key thing for me is to think globally and act locally.ldquoWhat we can do in East Lothian is be a real exemplar. We can really change things.Mr McLennan was joined by Dr Eurig Scandrett, lecturer at Queen Margaret University and former head of community action at Friends of the Earth Scotland.Dr Scandrett highlighted that the fact so many countries were now speaking about the problem was progress in itself.He added: ldquoAnd itrsquos not actually all humans that caused climate change.ldquoI didnrsquot make the decision to base our economy on fossil fuels.ldquoThe people who are making these decisions are actually a tiny proportion of the worldrsquos population.ldquoSome of us are fortunate enough to have some choices in our lestyles, and Irsquom sure the people here are doing things like that, using public transport, cycling and so on.ldquoWe have that choice ndash but the vast majority of people in the world donrsquot have that choice ndash whether theyrsquore on low incomes with poorly insulated houses, whether theyrsquore living up against the fence line of the oil refineries.ldquoThose of us who have choice need to use our voices to keep the pressure on.Mr McLennan and Dr Scandrett were joined by ious members of the vigil to share their thoughts, including five-year-old Rory, who said we need to plant more trees and move away from fossil fuels Siri, , who pointed out that ldquo you just use non-renewables all the time, eventually therersquos nothing left and Rab, , who said the pound.bn spent on nuclear weapons in the UK last year could have been used to transition to renewable energy.Lilia, , said: ldquoYou talk a lot about money and recycling and infrastructure.ldquoItrsquos easy to forget that large swathes of the population live in relative poverty.ldquoFunding and services need to be increased to educate everyone and reach everyone.Mr McLennan told the crowd he was impressed by the childrenrsquos level of engagement.He said: ldquoThe childrenrsquos knowledge and passion was incredible.Mr McLennan also joined Climate Action East Lintonon Saturday, at the newly refurbished high street phonebox, which was filled with messages on climate change by members of the local community.A CAEL spokesperson said: ldquoDespite the heavy rain, the atmosphere was really positive, friendly and informative, and many passers-by stopped for a chat and took away information leaflets.ldquoMr McLennan gave a short talk on his hopes for a coalition of East Lothian climate action groups, who all have the same aims and objectives, one of which is to work towards making East Lothian Scotlandrsquos first carbon-neutral region.ldquoHe also outlined the real prospects of job conversion opportunities and energy-saving house building for the area.The event ended with a candlelit vigil in the village square, where a piper played and poems were read.Further vigils will be held in East Linton tomorrowand next Thursday , pm to pm.

title: comedy-film-music-theatre-brunton-next-days
story: Midlothian comedian Eric Davidson brings his style of humour to The Brunton today . A regular at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, his poetry and musical parody has had audiences spellbound with his ldquoclever satirical wordplay.Classic lunchtime theatre is back, offering company, soup and a sandwich, and a short play. Rapturersquos new production of The Dock Brief tells the story of budgie fancier Herbert Fowle, who murdered his we because she laughed too much. The production, written by John Mortimer , stars Scottish theatre legend and award-winning performer John Bett as Morgenhall. It is live on stage this Saturday .A classical lunchtime concert on Tuesday will be performed by Toronto-born musician Tim Beattie, who has won prizes at international guitar competitions in many countries. Now a star student at the Royal Conservatoire of Scotland, he brings a programme of romantic music for guitar .The midweek movie next Wednesdayis Respect . Jenner Hudson stars as Queen of Soul Aretha Franklin in this epic biopic from director Liesl Tommy.Audiences, meanwhile, can relive the magic of the s with nine chart-topping acts at lsquoSixties Gold: the Ultimate Line Uprsquo on November , at .pm and .pm.It stars The Tremeloes, Mamas and Papas UK, Hermanrsquos Hermits, The Marmalade, PJ Proby, Dave Berry, Vanity Fare and Gerryrsquos Pacemakers.The Tremeloes have sold in excess of  million records worldwide, with their huge number one hits Silence Is Golden, Suddenly You Love Me, Even The Bad Times Are Good andNumber One.Hermanrsquos Hermits formed in Manchester in , chalked up  hit singles,  hit albums, appeared in three major movies and have sold in excess of  million records.Marmalade were the champions of the Scottish Beat in  PJ Proby was first invited to the UK by The Beatles Dave Berry had chart-topping hit The Crying Game Mamas and Papas UK will be performing songs including Calornia Dreaminrsquo and Gerryrsquos Pacemakers will perform hits including Yoursquoll Never Walk Alone.Tickets and information can be found at thebrunton

title: ban-motorcyclist-drove-grossly-excessive-speeds-a1
story: Richard Montgomery, of High Street, was caught driving a motorcycle dangerously by travelling at well over the speed limit on the A near to Gladsmuir.The -year-old pleaded guilty to the offence during an appearance at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Monday.Sherf Matthew Auchencloss handed Montgomery an interim driving ban and deferred sentence for background reports to later this month.Montgomery, a director of a golf tour business, admitted driving the motorcycle at grossly excessive speeds on the A on September  last year.

title: festive-market-dirleton-offering-christmas-gifts-weekend
story: Stallholders at Dirleton Market on the Green are getting in the festive spirit with a range of gts, from crafts to speciality foods, for sale.Also on offer will be a range of cards, photographic prints, fragranced gts and childrenrsquos wear.Pupils from the villagersquos primary school will be selling apple juice made from their orchard apples.A raffle is being held with a festive hamper prize, as well as a competition to guess how many dogs visit the market, which runs from am to pm.A spokesperson for the monthly market said: ldquoThe November market will be the first outing for some splendid gazebos with distinctive white canopies, which the market has been able to purchase with a National Lottery Award from the National Lottery Community Fund.ldquoThese gazebos make sturdy, weather-resistant shelters for the ious stalls and will look great on Dirletonrsquos beautul green.
